ORDER

The petitioner is a handicapped man and is a singer of some
repute. He faces accusation of having committed offence under
Sections 376(2)(n) and 506 of the IPC, and Section 67(A) of the
Information Technology Act, 2002, in S.C. No.1090 of 2017 on the
file of the Additional Sessions Court-I, Manjeri.

2. The 2" respondent, who was a married woman and the
mother of three children, lodged a complaint before the police on
02.01.2016 alleging that the petitioner herein, by threatening that
her explicit photographs would be circulated online, induced her to
have a sexual relationship with him. She was subjected to rape in
her house and in a hotel at Ooty in the year 2015. The crime was
investigated and final report was laid before the jurisdictional court.

3. The above criminal proceedings are sought to be quashed
by invoking the inherent powers of this Court under Section 482 of
the Cr.P.C.

4. The 2” respondent, who is the de facto complainant, has
filed an affidavit stating that she was in love with the petitioner

Cr1.MC.No. 8093 of 2018
3
herein and when this fact came to the knowledge of her near
relatives, they had forced her to lodge a complaint leveling false
accusations. According to the 2™ respondent, her former husband
has divorced her and she has now married the petitioner herein.
She would refer to Anneuxre-B certificate of marriage issued by the
Marriage Officer, Tirur to substantiate her contention. She would
also refer to Annexure-C affidavit sworn to by her and contended
that the continuance of criminal proceedings is an abuse of process
and would prove detrimental to her married life.

5. The learned counsel appearing for the petitioner
submitted that the petitioner is a renowned singer and the 2"
respondent had fallen in love with him. When the matter came to
the knowledge of her former husband, she was forced to lodge a
complaint. Immediately thereafter, both parties divorced their
respective spouses and have got married.

6. The learned Public Prosecutor was directed to get
instructions. It is submitted that the investigating officer has
recorded the statement of the victim and she has stated in clear
terms that she has no grievance against the petitioner herein.

_

7. I have considered the submissions advanced and have
perused the materials made available.

8. The legal position with regard to quashing of proceedings
on the basis of compromise between the parties is by now well
settled. It has been held that the power of the High Court in
quashing a criminal proceeding or FIR or complaint in exercise of its
inherent jurisdiction is distinct and different from the power given to
a criminal Court for compounding the offences under Section 320 of
the Code. In what cases power to quash the criminal proceeding or
complaint or FIR may be exercised where the offender and victim
have settled their dispute would depend on the facts and
circumstances of each case and no category can be prescribed.
However, before exercise of such power, the Court will have to give
due regard to the nature and gravity of the crime. It is also settled
that heinous and serious offences of mental depravity or offences
like murder, rape, dacoity, etc., cannot quashed even though the
victim or victim's family and the offender have settled the dispute.
Such offenses are not private in nature and have serious impact on
society. The directions of the Apex Court in Gian Singh v. State of

_
Bis
2019/KER/340
Cr1.MC.No. 8093 of 2018
5

Punjab [(2012) 10 SCC 303] and in Narinder singh v. State of
Punjab [(2014) 6 SCC 466 ] serve as guiding lights.

9. Insofar as the offence of rape is concerned, there cannot
be any doubt that the same cannot be settled on the strength of a
compromise arrived at between the victim and the accused. The
Apex Court in State of M.P. v. Madan Lal [2015 (7) SCC 681],
relying on the decision in Shimbhu_ and Another v. State _ of
Haryana [2014 (13) SCC 318] has clearly reminded the Courts that
rape is a non-compoundable offence and it is an offence against the
society and is not a matter to be left for the parties to compromise
and settle. This was because of the fact that the Court cannot
always be assured that the consent given by the victim in
compromising the case is a genuine consent. There is every chance
that the victim might have been pressurised by the accused or the
trauma undergone by her all the years might have compelled her to
opt for a compromise. In such cases, the accused may use all his
influence to pressurise the victim for a compromise. It was taking note
of this aspect that it was held that it would not be safe in considering
the compromise arrived at between the parties in rape cases.

_

Cr1.MC.No. 8093 of 2018

10. However, in the instant case, it is borne out from the
statement of the 2"? respondent recorded by the investigating officer
that the parties were in love and the Crime was registered due to
the circumstances prevailing then. Annexure-B would show that the
parties have married and they are living together as husband and
wife. There is no case for anyone that the dignity of the 2"
respondent was violated by a wanton act of the petitioner. This
is not one of those cases, wherein the allegations reek of
extreme depravity, perversity or cruelty. It cannot be said that the
offence in the instant case would fall in the category of offences that
have a serious impact on society. In the peculiar facts of the
instant case, grave hardship and inconvenience will be caused to
the 2™ respondent, if the prosecution is permitted to continue. She
has also filed an affidavit stating that she is not desirous of
prosecuting against her husband any further. In that view of the
matter, the prospects of an ultimate conviction is remote and bleak
even if the case is proceeded with. Furthermore, the 2" respondent
can continue with her life with dignity and respect. Having
considered all the relevant circumstances, I am _ of the
considered view that this is a fit case in which this Court will

be well justified in invoking its extraordinary powers under
Section 482 of the Code to quash the proceedings.

In the result this petition will stand allowed. Annexure-A Final
report and all further proceedings pursuant thereto against the
petitioner in SC No. 1090/2017 on the file of Additional Sessions
Court-I, Manjeri are quashed.
